worklogs.comment:
pitrou opened a new pull request #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005
 
 
   1. Get rid of all macros and sprinkled out hash table handling code
   
   2. Improve performance by more careful selection of hash functions
      (and better collision resolution strategy)
   
   Integer hashing benefits from a very fast specialization.
   Small string hashing benefits from a fast specialization with less branches
   and less computation.
   Generic string hashing falls back on Murmur2-64, which has probably sufficient
   performance given the typical distribution of string key length.
   
   3. Add some tests and benchmarks

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440331130
 
 
   For the record, the performance of the underlying hash functions:
   ```
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Benchmark                               Time           CPU Iterations
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   BM_HashIntegers/repeats:1              12 us         12 us      56717   12.0656GB/s
   BM_HashSmallStrings/repeats:1          84 us         84 us       8303   2.41023GB/s
   BM_HashMediumStrings/repeats:1        468 us        468 us       1497   2.77201GB/s
   ```

pitrou edited a comment on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440331130
 
 
   For the record, the performance of the underlying hash functions:
   ```
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   Benchmark                               Time           CPU Iterations
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------
   BM_HashIntegers/repeats:1              12 us         12 us      56717   12.0656GB/s
   BM_HashSmallStrings/repeats:1          84 us         84 us       8303   2.41023GB/s
   BM_HashMediumStrings/repeats:1        468 us        468 us       1497   2.77201GB/s
   ```
   
   The integer benchmark uses 64-bit ints, so it means we're hashing 1.5 billion 64-bits per second.

pitrou commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440338640
 
 
   I would like to refactor/simplify hardware CRC32 support but there's some intriguing comment in `sse-util.h` about Impala and SSE4.2-less CPUs. What's the status of that? All recent x86-64 CPUs [have SSE4.2 support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSE4#Supporting_CPUs). Both [IMPALA-1399](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IMPALA-1399) and [IMPALA-1646](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IMPALA-1646) are about _extremely_ old CPUs (probably 10 years old by now or more).
   
   @wesm 

----------------------------------------------------------------

   ```
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------

   BM_HashIntegers/repeats:1              12 us         12 us      56717   12.0656GB/s
   BM_HashSmallStrings/repeats:1          84 us         84 us       8303   2.41023GB/s
   BM_HashMediumStrings/repeats:1        468 us        468 us       1497   2.77201GB/s
   ```
   
   The integer benchmark uses 64-bit ints, so it means we're hashing 1.5 billion 64-bit ints per second.

pitrou edited a comment on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440338640
 
 
   I would like to refactor/simplify hardware CRC32 support but there's some intriguing comment in `sse-util.h` about Impala and SSE4.2-less CPUs. What's the status of that? All recent x86-64 CPUs [have SSE4.2 support](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSE4#Supporting_CPUs). Both [IMPALA-1399](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IMPALA-1399) and [IMPALA-1646](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/IMPALA-1646) are about _extremely_ old CPUs (probably 10 years old by now or more).
   
   @wesm @dhecht

   Also I don't understand why ARROW_USE_SSE is off by default, but we still do macro-based switching in `sse-util.h`. That sounds convoluted.

wesm commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440349286
 
 
   @pitrou this is great! I will review in more detail today and also respond to your comments. Indeed, there is some cruft from some of the Apache Impala code that was originally imported into parquet-cpp. 
   
   I have some hashing work I want to do in some places (e.g. deduplicating strings when converting to pandas), so this should put the hashing code on a more stable footing.

wesm commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440349933
 
 
   cc @timarmstrong if you can comment on what you've seen as far as CPUs without SSE4.2 support. 
   
   We need to support arm64 so we can't hard-code sse4.2 instructions, but we should optimistically use them if they are available.

users@infra.apache.org

pitrou commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440350529
 
 
   Ideally I would like to enable SSE4.2 at compile-time on all x86-64 targets (so just using preprocessor switches based on compiler-enabled macros, without either ARROW_USE_SSE or cpuid-based runtime switching). Also there are intrinsic functions that can avoid hand-written inline asm.

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

wesm commented on issue #3005: [WIP] ARROW-2653: [C++] Refactor hash table support
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3005#issuecomment-440353523
 
 
   Got it. I would be ok with adding `-msse4.2` by default when compiling on x86-64. I haven't tried running the Arrow unit tests on arm64 lately (I've tested both on a Tegra X1 and Raspberry Pi in the past) so after we do this someone should check that things still work there

issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

fields.description:
Currently our hash table support is scattered in several places:
 * {{compute/kernels/hash.cc}}
 * {{util/hash.h}} and {{util/hash.cc}}
 * {{builder.cc}} (in the DictionaryBuilder implementation)

Perhaps we should have something like a type-parametered hash table class (perhaps backed by non-owned memory) with several primitives:
 * decide allocation size for a given number of items
 * lookup an item
 * insert an item
 * decide whether resizing is needed
 * resize to a new memory area
 * ...

comments.body:
I agree with this, with the caveat that in my experience this type of code (hashing) is very performance sensitive. I've been surprised at the changes that can cause 30-50% change in execution time. 

Luckily, we have plenty of other hash table implementations in other projects to look at to see how efficient our implementations are relative to comparables

I have already started on that. The benchmarks on DictionaryBuilder are positive: i.e. the rewritten hash support performs slightly better. I haven't tried to migrate kernels yet, as that part seems a bit messier currently.

That's great to hear. AFAIK we aren't using any SSE4.2 intrinsics like crc32 for hashing yet, so based on what features the CPU supports we will eventually want to select a fast path vs. a compatible path
Basically I'm using [xxhash|https://cyan4973.github.io/xxHash/] (the 64-bit variant). There's also a special case for integers.
Apparently SSE4.2 (which includes the CRC instructions) is supported on all recent x86 CPUs: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSE4#SSE4.2
